summary: Two appeals have been made by the International Society for Krishna Consciousness (ISKCON) and its Vice President Chanchalpati Das against a charge-sheet filed against them by the West Bengal Police in connection with a complaint made by a former member of ISKCON. It is alleged that on 30.09.2006, the Kolkata Branch of ISKCON, Kolkata had sent a letter to the Ballygunge Police Station, Kolkata, alleging that a vehicle owned by the Branch Manager of ISKCON, Kolkata had been stolen by Mr. 58 in the court of Chief Judicial Magistrate, Alipore against the accused Madhu Pandit Das, Chanchalpati Das, Mahajan Das and Adridharan Das, for the offences under Section 468, 471, 406 and 120-B IPC on 230. Learned Senior Advocate K. Venugopal appearing on behalf of appellants submitted that the criminal proceedings against the appellants may not be quashed, as the offences alleged against the appellants are not compoundable under Section 320 of Cr.P.C.

summary: The Supreme Court of India has ruled that a person who takes an insurance policy to cover the risk of fire, during the course of Godhra riots, does not take the policy for the commercial purpose. The National Commission for Insurance has held that a person who takes a policy of insurance to cover a loss suffered is not ordinarily intended to generate profits. Learned counsel submits that the provision of insurance for commercial activities falling within the ambit of the Consumer Protection Act, 1986 is not available to the litigant who is aggrieved by the insurance contract as Section 2(1)(d) of the Act, 1986 and Section 2(7) of the Consumer Protection Act, 2019 Act specifically exclude the provisions of services “for commercial purpose” from the ambit of consumer courts and the only remedy lies to the commercial courts under the Act, 2015.

summary: The Bombay High Court has set aside an order of a lower court dismissing an application for discharge of a serving army captain and four others accused in a 2006 murder case. The case was triable under sections 302 of Cr.P.C. The High Court vide impugned order had set aside the order passed by the Trial Court and discharged Respondent Manjit Singh Virdi (Retd.) vs Hussain Mohammed Shattaf on 18 May, 2023 Kanoon - http://indiankanoon.org/doc/41862725/ 2Nos. The Supreme Court of India has held that a court does not have to enter into the pros and cons of evidence before framing charges in criminal cases.

summary: The Supreme Court of India has taken up an appeal against the Allahabad High Court's decision to reduce the interest on an arbitral award to 9% simple interest per annum. The appellant has challenged the High Court’s decision to reduce the statutory interest rate from 18% to 9% per annum on a claim of 3,00,000 awarded by the arbitrator for non-issuance of tender. The provisions of the Arbitration Act, 1940, as it stood on the date of award by the arbitrator in this case, were pre-amended by way of Section 31(7)(b) of the 1996 Act.

summary: The Supreme Court of India has taken up an appeal from a woman who was allegedly harassed by her husband and his family members after she filed a divorce petition against him. The High Court of Karnataka has directed the police to provide adequate police protection to a woman, who had filed a writ petition against her ex-husband, alleging that he had been harassing and threatening to kill her. The High Court of Andhra Pradesh in an impugned order dated 12.08.2020, granted bail to a man accused of hatching a criminal conspiracy in connection with the murder of a woman in the city of Visakhapatnam.

summary: A Division Bench of the Bombay High Court has issued notice to the State of Maharashtra and to the Central Bureau of Investigation (CBI) on an appeal by a civil engineer who was allegedly beaten up by the police for sharing a viral picture of the then Prime Minister Narendra Modi on Facebook. Here are the key points of the appeal: 3.1 It is submitted that as observed and held by this Court in the case of Dharam Pal Vs. State of Haryana and Ors., (2016) 4 SCC 160 (para 25), the Constitutional Courts are envisaged with the power to order fresh, de novo or re-investigation and as observed and held the commencement of a trial and examination of some witnesses cannot be an absolute impediment for exercising the said constitutional power, which is meant to ensure a fair and just investigation.

summary: Criminal Appeal Nos.4 and 5 and 6 (aps herein) who were convicted for the offences under Section 302 of the Indian Penal Code (for short ‘IPC’) by the Sessions Court came to be affirmed by the High Court of Punjab NEETA SAPRA. The appellants have been convicted and sentenced to life imprisonment by a Sessions Court in Panchkula for the offence of murder of Ajay, a minor boy, who was allegedly murdered by the appellants at their residence in Panchkula on the night of 9 October, 2013. The learned counsel for the appellant (A-4) would contend that the courts below had erred in not considering the fact that a person liable for being punished for the offence of being a member of an unlawful assembly under Section 149 IPC would be necessary to prove that such persons had acted in pursuance of a common object.

summary: Two appeals have been made against the orders of the Division Bench of the Punjab & Haryana High Court dismissing writ petitions filed by the former minister of state for finance, Pankaj Bansal and his father, Basant Bansal, challenging the arrest orders passed by the Vacation Judge/Additional Sessions Judge, Panchkula, whereby they were remanded to the custody of the Directorate of Enforcement (for money laundering, ‘the ED’) and thereafter, to judicial custody. The Enforcement Directorate (ED) filed its first Economic Crime Investigation Report (ECIR) in the Court of Sudhir Parmar, Special Judge, Panchkula, on 17 April, 2022. summary: The Supreme Court of India has taken up an appeal by a man who was sentenced to life imprisonment by the Delhi High Court for raping and murdering a 15-year-old girl in 2009. The appellant was convicted and sentenced to life imprisonment by the Trial Court for the murder of his two sons, PW-1 Shiv Kumar Yadav and PW-2 Shiv Kumar Yadav, who were found dead in a canal at Haiderpur in the state of Uttar Pradesh, on the complaint of the wife of the appellant. The appellant, Prem Singh, appeals against his conviction and sentence of life imprisonment imposed by the Court of Sessions, Delhi, for murdering his two sons.

summary: The High Court of Judicature at Bombay has granted leave to a cooperative society to appeal against a decision of a single judge of the High Court of Judicature at Bombay to remove approximately 2000 members of the society on the ground that they did not fulfill conditions of eligibility under the Maharashtra Co-operative Societies Act 1960. The appellants have challenged the order of the Regional Joint Director (Sugar) under Section 152 of the Maharashtra Cooperative Societies Act 1960, directing the deletion of 1415 members from the membership of a sugar factory. The Single Judge of the High Court has recorded the submission of the counsel appearing on behalf of the complainants that the Regional Joint Director and the appellate authority on factual aspects which have been affirmed by the dismissal of the writ petition under Article 226 of the Constitution of India.

summary: A ban on the manufacture, storage, supply, transport, sale, distribution, and use of plastic bags and paper cups in the state of Tamil Nadu has been upheld by the Supreme Court. summary: The Hyderabad High Court has issued notice to the Securities and Exchange Board of India and the Directorate of Enforcement on a plea by a former director of Farmax India Limited, Sanjay Raghunath Agarwal, challenging an order of the Metropolitan Magistrate, Cyberabad, registering a case against him for alleged offences under Sections 406, 407, 120B read with 34 of the Indian Penal Code. The Enforcement Directorate has filed a complaint against Shrijay Raghunath Agarwal, Shri Arun Panchariya, Shri Srinivas Reddy and others under the provisions of the Prevention of Money-laundering Act, 1988. On 20 April 2023, M/s Farmax India Limited was not eligible for USD 72.20 million GDR and hence was directly involved in the process and activity connected with the proceeds of crime including its acquisition and hence has committed the offence of money-laundering as defined under section 3 of PMLA, 2002 and is liable for punishment under Section 4 of PMLA, 2002.

summary: The High Court of Karnataka has dismissed the appeal of Bhimashankar Sahakariakkare against the arbitral award of Walchandnagar Industries Ltd. The Bombay High Court has ruled that the limitation period for filing an application for setting aside an arbitral award under Section 34 of the Arbitration Act, 1993 should be 30 days from the date on which the party making application has received the award. The Court of Appeal in the case of Assam Urban (Supra) has held that the High Court in the case of Assam Urban (Supra) did not notice or deal with Section 10 of the General Clauses Act, 1897.

summary: The Delhi High Court has reduced from 10 years to 7 years the substantive sentence passed by the Sessions Court for the offence of raping a prosecutrix. summary: The Uttarakhand High Court has upheld the conviction and sentence of Charan Singh @ Charanjit Singh for murdering his wife Chhilo Kaur. The appellant was convicted by the Uttarakhand High Court under Sections 304B, 498A and 201 IPC in connection with the death of his wife. summary: The Kerala High Court has upheld the levy of interest on an assessee for delay in remittance of tax deducted at source (TDS). The impugned common judgment and order passed by the High Court of India in the case of Us Technologies International Pvt. The Supreme Court has taken up the appeal of Reliance Industries Ltd against the order of the Kerala High Court which had held that an assessee who failed to remit tax deducted at source (TDS) was not liable to be prosecuted as per Section 276B of the Income Tax Act, 1961, as per which a person who fails to pay to the credit of the Central Government the tax deducted at source by him as required by or under the provisions of Chapter XVIIB, shall be liable to be prosecuted and shall be punishable with rigorous imprisonment for a term which shall not be less than three months but which may extend to seven years and with fine.

summary: The Supreme Court of India has taken up the appeal of an ex-Border Security Force (BSF) Commandant who was convicted and sentenced to life imprisonment by the Punjab and Haryana High Court for drug trafficking. The appellant, a serving Border Security Force (BSF) officer, was arrested by the BSF on 05.04.1995 for allegedly trying to smuggle arms and ammunition into India from Pakistan. It was contended in the appeal that the conviction and sentence of dismissal from service of the appellant for offences under the BSF Act and the NDPS Act is illegal as the appellant had retired on 31.08.1995, even before the issuance of the charge sheet in question and thus there cannot be any sentence of dismissal from service, which is made clear from Rule 166 of the Rules, which stipulate that the sentence of dismissal shall take effect from the date of promulgation of such sentence or from any subsequent date as may be specified at the time of promulgation, which in the present case is much after the superannuation of the appellant from service.

summary: The Supreme Court has ruled that cinema goers in Jammu and Kashmir are compelled to purchase food and beverages which are made available to them at "exorbitant" prices. The Jammu and Kashmir High Court in an impugned judgment and order issued on 3 January, 2023 has held: “Such acts of Multiplex/Cinema Hall owners are against the right to choice of food, including the right not to eat junk food and right to good health, which comes under the purview of Article 21 of the Constitution of India guaranteeing protection of life and personal liberty of every citizen.” This is an appeal from an impugned judgment of the High Court of Jammu and Kashmir which held that a cinema ticket issued by a cinema hall is a contract with the movie goer and in the absence of any prohibition on the printed terms of the ticket, a movie goer cannot be prevented from bringing eatables or beverages inside the cinema hall.

The National Green Tribunal (NGT) has dismissed all the petitions filed by theShramjeevi Cooperative Housing Society, Mandsaur, against the decision of the Collector, Mandsaur, to demarcate the boundaries of the talab, and to cancel the conversion certificate of the society, on the ground that its use for construction of residential units to its members (who were workers, belonging to the poorer segments of society), became a subject matter of a previous litigation, whereby the state authorities had cancelled the conversion certificate, on the ground that the lands fell in the submergence area. The National Green Tribunal (NGT) issued an impugned order on 22 March, 2023, in the case of Shriramjeevi Cooperative Housing Society vs Dinesh Joshi, Writ Petition No.

summary: The Supreme Court has issued notice to the North Delhi Municipal Corporation (NDMC) on a writ petition challenging a High Court ruling that an acquisition with respect to the land in question was deemed to have lapsed under Section 24(2) of the Right to Fair Compensation and Transparency in Land Acquisition, Rehabilitation and Resettlement Act, 2013. The High Court of Delhi has allowed a writ petition challenging the acquisition of land by the Delhi Municipal Corporation (DMC) under the Municipal Corporation Act, 2013 and has declared that the acquisition with respect to the land in question is deemed to have lapsed as the assessed compensation was never paid to the original owners - Bodey Singh or his successor-in-interest - Lal The Supreme Court of India has overruled two decisions of the High Court on the issue of lapse of land acquisition proceedings under Section 24(2) of the 2013 Act.

summary: The Supreme Court of India has ruled that a worker who suffered a permanent total disablement due to an accident should be compensated at the rate of 40% of her annual salary, rather than the 50% prescribed by the Workmen’s Compensation Commissioner. R-1 vs Oriental Insurance Company Ltd. on 17 July, 2023 Indian Kanoon - http://indiankanoon.org/doc/120467803/ R-2 vs Oriental Insurance Company Ltd. on 17 July, 2023 Indian Kanoon - http://indiankanoon.org/doc/120467803/ The Supreme Court of India has held that "total disablement, whether temporary or permanent, of a workman is to be on the basis of his incapacity to perform the work which he was capable of performing at the time of the accident resulting in such disablement".

summary: The Union of India has moved the Supreme Court against the judgment and order passed by the High Court of Delhi and the Central Administrative Tribunal rejecting their representation for the grant of pay scale of Rs.7500-12000 to the Junior Design Officers as allowed to the Civilian Technical Officers (Design), consequent to the implementation of the Fifth Central Pay Commission. The appellant-UOI was aggrieved by the order passed by the National Human Rights Tribunal (NHTC) on the ground that the posts of Junior Commissioned Officers (JCOs) were equivalent to posts of Civilian Technical Officers (CTOs). The appellant-Association made the following submissions- (i) The Fifth Pay Commission had ignored the fact that from the very beginning, the posts of JDOs and CTOs (Design) carried the same pay scales, as they were having the same duties and responsibilities.

summary: The High Court of Delhi has held that the acquisition of land for development of Delhi has lapsed and the compensation therefor should be paid to the land owners. The arguments raised by learned counsel for the petitioners are that the High Court had erred in holding that the land acquisition proceedings under the 2013 Act had lapsed. Section 24(2) of the 2013 Act provides for a deemed lapse of proceedings in a proceeding for land acquisition pending with the authority concerned as on 112014.

summary: The State of Goa vs Summit Online Trade Solutions (P) Ltd on 14 March, 2023 Three writ petitions have been filed in the Delhi High Court challenging the constitutional validity of the Goods and Services Tax (GST) Act, 2017. The High Court was of the view that the writ petitioners were aggrieved not only by the impugned notification issued by the appellant under the GGST Act but also by the act of the Central Government in issuing the impugned notifications under the CGST Act as well as the IGST Act seeking to levy tax on lotteries organized, promoted and conducted by the State of Sikkim.

summary: The Kerala High Court has ruled that a man who had acquired title to land on which he had been in possession and in continued enjoyment, since 1940, was rightfully entitled to it. The Kerala High Court in its judgement dated 5th August, 2009 examined the decisions that led to the appeal before it and held that the lower Appellate Court’s approach stating that the suit was barred by virtue of the Act was not a good law, as the suit filed by the respondents herein was a suit for declaration of perfected title by virtue of adverse possession and not, a challenge against the notice issued by the Tahsildar. There are a number of criteria that must be met before a second appeal can be heard by the High Court.

summary: The Supreme Court of India has given its verdict in a case relating to the acquisition of land by the Central Corporation in the state of Haryana. The appellant, Reliance Industries Ltd., was acquired by the respondent, Haryana Urban Development Authority, under Section 18 of the 1894 Act, for the purpose of setting up a power plant in the Abadi near the Naraingarh District as well as near the sector carved by Haryana Urban Development Authority and was also near the Government College, Naraingarh and Government Senior Secondary School, Naraingarh. Reliance was placed upon a judgment dated 30.08.2000 of the Reference Court pertaining to acquisition of land in the year 1989 of the same village (Naraingarh), wherein the Reference Court had fixed the rate at Rs.2720/- per Marla equivalent to Rs.89.91 per square yard. summary: The Supreme Court of India has issued notice to the Enforcement Directorate on a writ petition challenging a summon issued by a special court in connection with a money-laundering case against a woman who had campaigned against the so-called swine flu. A writ petition has been filed in the Court of the Special Judge, Anti-Corruption, CBI Court No.1, Ghaziabad, challenging an order of the Special Judge, Anti-Corruption, CBI Court No.1, Ghaziabad, passing an order on provisional attachment of immovable property of the petitioner in connection with a money-laundering case. It is contended by the learned Solicitor General that under the provisions of the Prevention of Money-laundering Act (PMLA), the complaint of money-laundering should follow the complaint in respect of the scheduled offence.

summary: The Supreme Court of India has taken up the appeal of Jitendra Kumar Rode, convicted under the Prevention of Corruption Act, 1988. summary: The Supreme Court of India has upheld a lower court's order evicting a man from a suit premises in Delhi. In this case, the plaintiff-respondent has filed a suit against the defendant-appellant for eviction from the suit property on the ground that the defendant-appellant has entered into an agreement to sell the suit property in favour of the plaintiff-respondent in part performance of the agreement.
